Executive Summary


The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies for Loxahatchee River District (District) Wastewater Treatment Facility are structured to reduce the risk of injury to employees and the public from accidental release of chemicals.  The District?s program provides all information necessary to properly manage the regulated chemical ? Chlorine.
Plant Personnel are trained in the safe handling and use of Chlorine and are provided with the necessary safety equipment for working in proximity with this substance.
It is the District?s policy to utilize the Palm Beach County Fire Department?s HAZMAT team to respond to all major emergency conditions.
The District?s Wastewater Treatment Facility is a 9.0 mgd activated sludge treatment process which serves a 73-square mile area and includes the municipalities of Jupiter, Juno Beach, Tequesta, Northern Palm Beach County, and Southern Martin County.
The plant utilizes chlorine gas for disinfection of the plant effluent prior to distribution to the reuse system.  The maximum quantity of chlorine stored on-site is 16,000 lbs. in the form of 8 1-ton cylinders.

The worst case release scenario involves the release of 2,000 lbs. of chlorine gas from a ruptured ton cylinder.  The area of impact is a 2.6 mile radius from the chlorine storage facility.  In the unlikely event of such a release, off-site impacts would occur and include risk to public and private receptors, such as schools, businesses, and residences.

The alternative release scenario involves the release of 780 lbs. of chlorine gas from a leaking transfer hose.  Area of impact is a 938 yard radius from the chlorine storage facility which will impact a small industrial business park.  There are no off-site environmental impacts associated with this scenario.

The District?s Wastewater Treatment Facility complies with all requirements stipulated in EPA 40 CFR Part 68 ?Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:
Risk Management Program? an

d OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 ?Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals?
There has been no accidental release of chlorine in the past 5 years.  The District?s policy is to contact the Palm Beach County Fire Rescue HAZMAT Team to handle all major releases of chlorine.

The District has instituted an inter-active training program that is mandatory for all operation and maintenance personnel to complete.  All contractors and sub-contractors are required to complete the inter-active training module prior to working on the plant site.

The District is committed to it?s ongoing safety training to ensure proper safety at the facility.
